pullRequest.body:
Add a file `Algebra/Ring/Ext`, proving `ext` lemmas for all of the ring-like classes (for example, anything from `NonUnitalNonAssocSemiring` to `CommRing`), stating that two instances of such a class are equal if they define the same addition and multiplication operations.
Also prove `ext_iff` variants for each class, and injectivity lemmas for projections from classes to parent classes.

---
Some notes:
+ Things I didn't do because they don't seem particularly necessary:
  + I skipped `HasDistribNeg`.
  + More injectivity lemmas could be proved between the `Comm` variants (currently it's just from `Comm` variant to non-`Comm` variant for each).
+ A natural next step would be to extend this to `DivisionSemiring`, `DivisionRing`, `Semifield` and `Field`.
+ I have introduced local notation to eliminate some boilerplate. I'm not sure if this is style-appropriate for Mathlib (although the notation is local to one file and (probably) never shows up when e.g. the types of lemmas are viewed, so that it's invisible to anyone not editing this file).
+ In [another branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/raghuram-13/ext-for-rings.experimental), I have used a (local) custom command to generate the `ext` and `ext_iff` lemmas, eliminating even more boilerplate.

  It should be possible to extend that command to be more general (such as allowing `declModifiers` and `terminationSuffix` clauses, allowing a custom theorem name defaulting to `ext`, specifying the type for which an ext lemma is being proved, specifying the arguments, and letting the names be inaccessible by default while allowing them to be specified with a "with" clause), in which case it could become a useful command for writing extensionality lemmas (admittedly partially overlapping in functionality with putting an `@[ext]` on the type definition).

+ I haven't written any tests — I'm not sure what to test or how to write tests.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

Sorry for the late response, this dropped somewhat off my radar. The code looks good to me. Still have some small remarks about the comments.

bors d+

```suggestion
Copyright (c) 2024 Raghuram Sundararajan. All rights reserved.
```
Happy new year!

In the other ext lemmas, we write
```suggestion
    (h_mul : (letI := inst₁; HAdd.hAdd : R → R → R) = (letI := inst₂; HAdd.hAdd : R → R → R)) 
```
Can we do the same here? That probably also removes the need for `funext` below.

I thought that in practice equality of functions would mostly be proved by extensionality and so this would "shift" the need to use `funext` from uses to here, making the lemmas more usable.

For reference, I found two uses of the extensionality lemmas from `Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Ext`, in both of which the argument is proved using `funext`:
- `Group.ext` used in `Mathlib.Topology.Homotopy.HomotopyGroup`, around line 526
-  `AddCommGroup.ext` used in `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Preadditive.Biproducts`, around line 657

Of course, I can also go ahead and change everything to "function equality" from "application equality".

By the way, I noticed that `Group.ext` and `CommGroup.ext` in `Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Ext.lean` use `g.mul` rather than `(letI := g; HMul.hMul: G → G → G)`, which goes against what is written at the top of that file.

Should this be changed (in a different PR)?
What lemma does `@[ext]` generate for `Distrib`? Is it the same?

The `@[ext]` in my code just registers the `ext` lemma I have proved for the `ext` tactic, as far as I know.

In case you mean what an `@[ext]` added to the definition of `Distrib` would do, it appears to be something more along the lines of `inst₁.toMul = inst₂.toMul → inst₁.toAdd = inst₂.toAdd → inst₁ = inst₂`.

I agree with @urkud that we should follow the format of the `Distrib.ext` lemma which is generated by `@[ext] class Distrib`. In fact, [there is a library `note [partially-applied ext lemmas]` about this](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/notes.html#partially-applied%20ext%20lemmas) (sadly never ported to Lean 4):

> When possible, `ext` lemmas are stated without a full set of arguments. As an example, for bundled
homs `f`, `g`, and `of`, `f.comp of = g.comp of → f = g` is a better `ext` lemma than
`(∀ x, f (of x) = g (of x)) → f = g`, as the former allows a second type-specific extensionality
lemmas to be applied to `f.comp of = g.comp of`.
If the domain of `of` is `ℕ` or `ℤ` and `of` is a `ring_hom`, such a lemma could then make the goal
`f (of 1) = g (of 1)`.
> 
> For bundled morphisms, there is a `ext` lemma that always applies of the form
`(∀ x, ⇑f x = ⇑g x) → f = g`. When adding type-specific `ext` lemmas like the one above, we want
these to be tried first. This happens automatically since the type-specific lemmas are inevitably
defined later.

So in this case we would use the unapplied `HAdd.add` and `HMul.mul`. (Note that `@[ext] class Distrib` is not quite right: it uses `Add.add` and `Mul.mul`, which means we don't get the nice notation.)
In fact Eric has an in-depth explanation of why we shouldn't apply `ext` lemmas in his dissertation: https://eric-wieser.github.io/thesis/eric-wieser-thesis.pdf (chapter 5).

That's a very good point for bundled morphisms, but I'm not sure that it applies to functions, where passing back from an "applied" goal `forall x y, f x y = g x y` to an "unapplied" goal `f = g` is a couple of `congr`s or so away for automation (unlike a bundled morphism, where one might have to reconstruct the bundled stuff if it has been simplified away), and as I mentioned above, it does seem like the "applied" goal is more often desired when used manually.

But in any case, I have changed everything to use "unapplied" ext subgoals in fbee3e7 (it was just a find-and-replace followed by patching proofs, but I don't *think* there are any errors in it now; still waiting for CI to finish).
(If this ever needs to be changed back, that and the three commits before it can be reverted.)
We don't have these `ext_iff` versions for `Monoid` and friends (and I suspect they're not actually useful), so I'd be inclined to skip them for now.

I added them because the `ext` attribute generates them for `class` definitions (probably `structure` and `inductive` as well).

Searching through Mathlib does turn up several uses of `ext_iff` lemmas, both as `ext_iff.1`/`ext_iff.mp` (which I guess is essentially a convenient way to avoid having to incant the right `congr` or `injection`s) and in `simp`s, although I don't know if these ones are going to be of any use.

I guess there's no harm in keeping these, even if we don't keep writing them?

One thing I did notice is that for `ext_iff` to be usable as `ext_iff.1`/`ext_iff.mp`, it should only take instance or implicit arguments (although this is not the behaviour of `@[ext]`-generated `ext_iff` lemmas).
If these `ext_iff` are kept, they could be changed to do the same (or not).

Now that they are written, I don't see much harm in keeping the `ext_iff`s. In this case the autogeneration behaviour of `@[ext]` is probably the wrong thing to do: as a rule of thumb, arguments that appear on both sides of an `iff` can be safely left implicit.

Here's another way to write the proof. Using `rintro rfl` means both sides are immediately equal, so no `congr` is needed. But either way is fine really.
```suggestion
theorem ext_iff (inst₁ inst₂ : Distrib R) :
    inst₁ = inst₂ ↔
      (∀ x y, x +[R, inst₁] y = x +[R, inst₂] y)
      ∧ (∀ x y, x *[R, inst₁] y = x *[R, inst₂] y) :=
  ⟨by rintro rfl; constructor <;> (intros; rfl), And.elim (ext · ·)⟩
```

The alternative proof came in useful after other refactoring; thanks!
I also changed the `ext_iff` arguments to implicit.
We should certainly add an ext lemma for `AddMonoidWithOne`

Sure; where though?
After the definition of `AddMonoidWithOne` in `Mathlib/Data/Nat/Cast/Defs.lean`, or in a new `Ext.lean` file in the same folder, or in `Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Ext.lean`, or in this file `Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Ext.lean`? (Or anywhere else?)

For now, here is an implementation which I (or someone else) can put in the appropriate file once decided:
```lean
/- Should the argument order be this or swapped? -/
@[ext] theorem AddMonoidWithOne.ext ⦃inst₁ inst₂ : AddMonoidWithOne R⦄
    (h_add : ∀ x y, x +[R, inst₁] y = x +[R, inst₂] y)
    (h_one : (letI := inst₁; One.one : R) = (letI := inst₂; One.one : R)) :
    inst₁ = inst₂ := by
  have h_monoid : inst₁.toAddMonoid = inst₂.toAddMonoid := by ext; apply h_add
  have h_zero' : inst₁.toZero = inst₂.toZero := congrArg (·.toZero) h_monoid
  have h_one' : inst₁.toOne = inst₂.toOne :=
    congrArg One.mk h_one
  have h_natCast : inst₁.toNatCast.natCast = inst₂.toNatCast.natCast := by
    funext n; induction n with
    | zero     => rewrite [inst₁.natCast_zero, inst₂.natCast_zero]
                  exact congrArg (@Zero.zero R) h_zero'
    | succ n h => rw [inst₁.natCast_succ, inst₂.natCast_succ, h_add]
                  exact congrArg₂ _ h h_one
  rcases inst₁ with @⟨⟨⟩⟩; rcases inst₂ with @⟨⟨⟩⟩
  congr

theorem AddCommMonoidWithOne.toAddMonoidWithOne_injective :
    Function.Injective (@AddCommMonoidWithOne.toAddMonoidWithOne R) := by
  rintro ⟨⟩ ⟨⟩ _; congr

@[ext] theorem AddCommMonoidWithOne.ext ⦃inst₁ inst₂ : AddCommMonoidWithOne R⦄
    (h_add : ∀ x y, x +[R, inst₁] y = x +[R, inst₂] y)
    (h_one : (letI := inst₁; One.one : R) = (letI := inst₂; One.one : R)) :
    inst₁ = inst₂ :=
  AddCommMonoidWithOne.toAddMonoidWithOne_injective <|
    AddMonoidWithOne.ext h_add h_one
```

(The proof of `NonAssocSemiring.ext` can be modified as follows.)
```diff
-  -- Mathematically non-trivial fact: `natCast` is determined by `0`, `1` and `+`.
-  have h_natCast : inst₁.toNatCast.natCast = inst₂.toNatCast.natCast := by
-    funext n; induction n with
-    | zero     => rewrite [inst₁.natCast_zero, inst₂.natCast_zero]; exact h_zero
-    | succ n h => rw [inst₁.natCast_succ, inst₂.natCast_succ, h_add]
-                  exact congrArg₂ _ h h_one
+  have : inst₁.toAddCommMonoidWithOne = inst₂.toAddCommMonoidWithOne :=
+    by ext <;> apply_assumption
+  have : inst₁.toNatCast = inst₂.toNatCast :=
+    congrArg (·.toNatCast) this
   -- Split into `NonUnitalNonAssocSemiring`, `One` instances, `natCast` function and properties.
-  rcases inst₁ with @⟨_, _, _, _, ⟨⟩⟩; rcases inst₂ with @⟨_, _, _, _, ⟨⟩⟩
+  cases inst₁; cases inst₂
```

(I can't figure out how to show this as a suggested code change.)

> or in this file Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Ext.lean?

I think this is fine. Anywhere is better than in a PR comment!
Done in 309b6ed6da and ce9756779c.
This should go into `AddGroupWithOne.ext`
Same question as for `AddMonoidWithOne`.

And here's an implementation to use later as with `AddMonoidWithOne`:
```lean
@[ext] theorem AddGroupWithOne.ext ⦃inst₁ inst₂ : AddGroupWithOne R⦄
    (h_add : ∀ x y, x +[R, inst₁] y = x +[R, inst₂] y)
    (h_one : (letI := inst₁; One.one : R) = (letI := inst₂; One.one)) :
    inst₁ = inst₂ := by
  have : inst₁.toAddMonoidWithOne = inst₂.toAddMonoidWithOne :=
    AddMonoidWithOne.ext h_add h_one
  have : inst₁.toNatCast = inst₂.toNatCast := congrArg (·.toNatCast) this
  have h_group : inst₁.toAddGroup = inst₂.toAddGroup := by ext; apply h_add
  -- Extract equality of necessary substructures from h_group
  injection h_group with h_group; injection h_group
  have : inst₁.toIntCast.intCast = inst₂.toIntCast.intCast := by
    funext n; cases n with
    | ofNat n   => rewrite [← Int.coe_nat_eq, inst₁.intCast_ofNat, inst₂.intCast_ofNat]; congr
    | negSucc n => rewrite [inst₁.intCast_negSucc, inst₂.intCast_negSucc]; congr
  rcases inst₁ with @⟨⟨⟩⟩; rcases inst₂ with @⟨⟨⟩⟩
  congr

@[ext] theorem AddCommGroupWithOne.ext ⦃inst₁ inst₂ : AddCommGroupWithOne R⦄
    (h_add : ∀ x y, x +[R, inst₁] y = x +[R, inst₂] y)
    (h_one : (letI := inst₁; One.one : R) = (letI := inst₂; One.one)) :
    inst₁ = inst₂ := by
  have : inst₁.toAddCommGroup = inst₂.toAddCommGroup :=
    AddCommGroup.ext (funext₂ h_add)
  have : inst₁.toAddGroupWithOne = inst₂.toAddGroupWithOne :=
    AddGroupWithOne.ext h_add h_one
  injection this with _ h_addMonoidWithOne; injection h_addMonoidWithOne
  cases inst₁; cases inst₂
  congr
```

(And the change in `NonAssocRing.ext`.)
```diff
   have h₂ : inst₁.toNonAssocSemiring = inst₂.toNonAssocSemiring := by
     ext <;> apply_assumption
-  -- Mathematically non-trivial fact: `intCast` is determined by the rest.
-  have h_intCast : inst₁.toIntCast.intCast = inst₂.toIntCast.intCast := by
-    have : inst₁.toNatCast = inst₂.toNatCast := by injection h₂
-    funext n; cases n with
-    | ofNat n   => rewrite [← Int.coe_nat_eq, inst₁.intCast_ofNat, inst₂.intCast_ofNat]; congr
-    | negSucc n => rewrite [inst₁.intCast_negSucc, inst₂.intCast_negSucc]; congr
-  -- Split into fields (extracting `intCast` function) and prove they are equal using the above.
-  rcases inst₁ with @⟨_, _, _, _, _, _, _, ⟨⟩⟩
-  rcases inst₂ with @⟨_, _, _, _, _, _, _, ⟨⟩⟩
-  congr <;> try solve| injection h₁ | injection h₂
+  have h₃ : inst₁.toAddCommGroupWithOne = inst₂.toAddCommGroupWithOne :=
+    AddCommGroupWithOne.ext h_add (congrArg (·.toOne.one) h₂)
+  cases inst₁; cases inst₂
+  congr <;> solve| injection h₁ | injection h₂ | injection h₃
```
Added in 309b6ed6da.

```suggestion
multiplication specified by a typeclass instance `i` on a type `R` (and similarly for addition). We
```

```suggestion
Since `Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Ext` proved several injectivity lemmas, we do so as well — even if sometimes we
```
Maybe with `.` instead of `/`?
I think `Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Ext.lean` is probably the best bet, since that is easier to detect heuristically in doc-gen for linkification.

IIRC I copied this style of referring to files from the commit conventions.

OTOH, I see the `.` style in the module header for `Algebra.Group.Defs` (without the `Mathlib` prefix), the `/` style (without `Mathlib` prefix, with `.lean` suffix) in `Algebra/Group/Basic.lean` and `Algebra/Group/UniqueProds.lean`, etc.

It's also noteworthy that the [contribution guidelines for documentation](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html) mention that fully-qualified names (e.g., `Group.ext`) are turned into links to the online docs, so that could cause a conflict if `.`-style notation is used to refer to modules and there is a definition and a module with the same name eventually (although that's unlikely if the `Mathlib` prefix is used for the module names).

So which style should I go with?
Let's use the `/` style for filenames. It's very easy to change that to dot notation later in a mathlib-wide sweep, but changing in the other direction is much harder.
Done in 10abca9012.

A commented-out line that is no longer needed can be safely deleted (we can always check the commits to get it back).
```suggestion
```
Must have forgotten to remove it long ago!

Nitpick: we put operators before a linebreak. Could you also make the same change below?
```suggestion
      (∀ x y, x +[R, inst₁] y = x +[R, inst₂] y) ∧
        (∀ x y, x *[R, inst₁] y = x *[R, inst₂] y) :=
```
Would it work to move these results to `Mathlib/Algebra/Group/WithOne/Basic.lean`? The same for `AddGroupWithOne`.

`Mathlib/Algebra/Group/WithOne` appears to be about an operator `WithOne` which adjoins a new zero/one to a type/algebraic structure, rather than about algebraic structures which already have one.

The `AddMonoidWithOne` etc. about which we have extra ext lemmas here are all defined in `Mathlib/Data/Nat/Cast/Defs.lean` or `Mathlib/Data/Int/Cast/Defs.lean`. As to where that means their ext lemmas should be placed, :shrug:. There is a resemblance in name to the classes of `Mathlib/Algebra/GroupWithZero`...
I see! The reason we have `AddMonoidWithOne` is somewhat of an implementation detail of rings, so I suppose it's fine if the results stay here.
Please move this comment to `section NonAssocSemiring`.

It's currently here because until the three lemmas following are relocated, they are functionally auxiliary lemmas for `NonAssocSemiring` extensionality. When those are moved, this will end up being at `namespace NonAssocSemiring` as desired.

I understand your point. However, pull requests should be self-contained, so comments etc. should reflect the actual state of the code, and not the proposed future state.

How about:
```suggestion
/-! ### NonAssocSemiring and its ancestors

This section also includes results for `AddMonoidWithOne`, `AddCommMonoidWithOne`, etc.
as these are considered implementation detail of the ring classes.
TODO consider relocating these lemmas.
-/
```

```suggestion
/-! ### NonAssocRing and its ancestors

This section also includes results for `AddGroupWithOne`, `AddCommGroupWithOne`, etc.
as these are considered implementation detail of the ring classes.
TODO consider relocating these lemmas. -/
```
